thread.title: Stanford faces Arizona in a rare Pac-12 meeting
thread.title_full: Stanford faces Arizona in a rare Pac-12 meeting

author:
Jon Wilner

jwilner@mercurynews.com
title: Stanford faces Arizona in a rare Pac-12 meeting
text:
Posted: 10/01/2015 11:01:06 AM PDT Updated: 10/01/2015 11:01:08 AM PDT Stanford's Homecoming isn't for three more weeks, but Saturday's duel with Arizona feels like a reunion. 
The teams haven't tangled in three years. 
The Cardinal has played Notre Dame three times and Army twice since it last faced Arizona, on the first Saturday of October 2012. 
Stanford rallied for a 54-48 overtime victory that day behind quarterback Josh Nunes. 
Alex Smith was the 49ers' quarterback the next day. 
The Giants were playing the Cincinnati Reds in the National League Division Series that weekend. 
The iPhone 5 had just been released. 
What gives with the 36-month hiatus in an intra-conference series that dates to 1979? 
Institutional politics, that's what. 
The Pac-12's four California schools insisted on playing each other annually when the conference split into six-team divisions in 2011. Stanford plays all the teams in the North, plus USC and UCLA -- that's seven of its nine league games. 
The other two games rotate among the Arizona and Mountain schools on a home-and-home basis. 
Stanford played Utah and Arizona State in 2013-14. It faces Colorado and Arizona in 2015-16. (Cal is on the opposite schedule.) 
"It's good, it's healthy, because the alternatives aren't good," Cardinal coach David Shaw said of the schedule rotation. 
"The alternatives are not playing USC and UCLA every year, and that hasn't been acceptable to any of the four (California) schools. It's not acceptable to our administration, and it's not acceptable to our alumni. Advertisement 
"Given that, this is best of both worlds." 
Arizona quarterback Anu Solomon, who suffered a concussion in the loss to UCLA, is day-to-day. 
"His status for the game is certainly in question," Wildcats coach Rich Rodriguez said. "We will see how he responds every day. They will do tests every day."
